context: Other notable new vaccines of the period include those for measles (<a5_0>1962<a5_0/>, <a1_0><b11_0>John Franklin Enders<b11_0/><a1_0/> of Children's Medical Center Boston, later refined by <a4_0><a6_0><b14_0>Maurice Hilleman<b14_0/><a6_0/><a4_0/> at Merck), Rubella (<a3_0><b13_0>1969<b13_0/><a3_0/>, Hilleman, Merck) and mumps (<a7_0>1967<a7_0/>, Hilleman, Merck) The United States incidences of rubella, congenital rubella syndrome, measles, and mumps all fell by <a2_0><a8_0><b12_0>>95%<b12_0/><a8_0/><a2_0/> in the immediate aftermath of widespread vaccination. The first 20 years of licensed measles vaccination in the U.S. prevented <a0_0><b10_0>an estimated <a9_0>52 million<a9_0/> cases of the disease, 17,400 cases of mental retardation, and 5,200 deaths<b10_0/><a0_0/>.
